utterances: He knows what he doesn't know, which is a great asset in a politician.
And so he is surrounding himself with individuals who complement his weaker areas.
Just who is backing Pena Nieto was a major issue in the hard-fought presidential campaign.
Pena Nieto campaigned as the fresh face of the PRI, more modern and democratic than his party's old apparatus which ruled Mexico through corruption and vote rigging for most of last century.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)

But as Pena Nieto's cabinet was announced to a packed hotel ballroom Friday, a few of the so-called dinosaurs from past PRI administrations did show up in the line-up, alongside several young picks all with impressive foreign degrees and experience.
Despite the mixed picture, Carlos Ramirez, a political risk strategist with the Eurasia Group says U.S.
investors like what they see in Pena Nieto and his advisors.
There is probably the best economic and political environment of the past four or five administrations.

Mexico's manufacturing exports are up, the country's more competitive than ever with China and Pena Nieto has already shown some political muscle in helping get a new labor reform bill through the lame-duck Congress.
But Ramirez says Pena Nieto faces enormous challenges too, including entrenched corruption and virtual monopolies in key economic sectors, like oil and telecommunications.
He says Pena Nieto has made some big promises.
It is something that could play in his favor but at the same time it could backfire if he is not able to deliver.
And Ramirez says pessimistically it wouldn't be the first time a Mexican president fell short of expectations.
Carrie Kahn, NPR News, Mexico City.
This is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Farai Chideya.
Today little Jena, Louisiana, may see more traffic than its had in a long time - traffic from Chicago, Detroit, Atlanta, Brooklyn, Philadelphia, and more.
Caravans are crossing the country to support the half-dozen young black men now known as the Jena Six.
They are accused of beating a white classmate, but advocates argue the Jena Six could face prison time far out of proportion to the alleged crimes.
Opposition to the way the case has been handled has grown so loud that President Bush found himself addressing the issue in a press conference this morning.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: The events in Louisiana are - it saddened me.
I understand the emotions.
The Justice Department and the FBI are - they're monitoring the situation down there, and all of us in America want there to be, you know, fairness when it comes to justice.
ColorOfChange.org, a national online advocacy group, is coordinating today's national day of action in support of the six accused teens.
Morehouse student Reginald McKinley organized over a hundred students himself for Morehouse, Spelman College and Clark Atlanta University.
I spoke with him yesterday as he was beginning his journey South, and he said he first heard about the case, not in the news, but online.
I actually was looking through some different sites, and I read a story about the Jena Six, approximately a month ago, on Facebook.
Now, a lot of people think that Facebook is a place where you go scribble on people's walls and you find people to date.
Were you surprised to find something this serious that you wanted to organize around?
There is no way I can tell you how much I love you.
Thanks for being my angel.
(Unintelligible) Honey, I love you so much.
You are the greatest wife ever.
Thank God I made him happy.
Lena met Jimmy Ahearn four years ago on an early May morning in Baghdad's Green Zone.
He was the captain in charge of her neighborhood.
Jimmy knew local thugs wanted to evict Lena's family from their spacious home, so he knocked on her door to find out what was going on.
She opened it and a blue-eyed American was standing there with the most beautiful smile she had ever seen.
I said, wow, that's a nice-looking man.
And as soon as he saw me, he said, wow, look at the Iraqi woman, all of them, they're all so pretty.
It looks like love at first sight, but we don't want to like say it.
Soon Jimmy started coming by every evening.
They would sit and chat in her mother's courtyard for hours.
It wasn't long before they were talking about getting married.
According to Muslim law, Lena couldn't marry Jimmy unless he converted.
I told him, if you believe in my religion, I don't want you to change it just because you want to marry me.
No. And he says, I believe in Islam, that's why, not because of you.
I'm going to change it.
Lena says Jimmy worked hard to bridge the cultural gaps between Iraqi Muslims and American troops.
Lena's family fell in love with Jimmy too.
They admired the way he treated residents of the neighborhood.
He gave food to people who were hungry.
He bought a hundred soccer balls for children to play with.
Marianne Barajas(ph) is Lena's younger sister.
Ms.
MARIANNE BARAJAS(ph) (Lena's Sister): Jimmy's such a good man.
He did a lot, not just for like my family or for Lena.
He did for the Iraqis in the Green Zone.
He was - he took care of a lot of things.
Such a great man.
There's only going to be one Jimmy.
Major Jimmy Ahearn was the oldest of four children.
He grew up in Concorde, California, not far from San Francisco.
According to his younger brother, Kevin, Jimmy was the kind of big brother who was worth looking up to.
He loved to go to baseball games and ride his mountain bike.
And, Kevin says, Jimmy never knew a stranger.
He was out - hand out every time we met somebody.
And he'd know their whole life story by the time we left.
In fact, there would be times when, like, okay, we're going to be late for this movie if you don't get moving.
Jimmy had been married before.
But Kevin says finding Lena changed his brother completely.
It was the first time he'd lived for anybody other than himself.
And then to find out that they were going to have a child together took him to a whole new level.
I mean he just lived for that little girl.
Kevin says Jimmy wasn't thrilled when he was called to go back to Iraq last spring.
By then he and Lena and their baby daughter were happily settled in North Carolina.
But Jimmy went, as the head of a civil affairs team that worked with local sheikhs and officials in the swathe of southern Baghdad.
He was on patrol when he died.
James Ahearn will be laid to rest at Arlington National Cemetery.
His widow plans to move to the Washington, D.C.
area to be closer to his grave.
She says she's ashamed that her country killed her husband.
Now Lena Ahearn plans to give up her Iraqi citizenship to become an American.
For NPR News, I'm Jessica Jones in Durham North Carolina.
This is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Tony Cox.
On today's Roundtable, the president's address to the United Nations and what it may mean to the war on terror and the image of the U.S.
in the Middle East.
Plus, celebrity voices join the push to end the genocide in Darfur.
But is anybody listening?
And in a new study whites speak out about being white.
Joining us today from our New York bureau are all three of our distinguished guests.
Michael Meyers, executive director of the New York Civil Rights Coalition, E.R.
Shipp, professor in journalism at Hofstra University School of Communication, and John McWhorter, Manhattan Institute senior fellow in public policy.
Everybody, welcome to the Roundtable today.
Thank you.
Thank you, Tony.
Let's begin here.
President Bush addressed the United Nations yesterday, we all know that.
And he asked during his appearance the world leaders to back his freedom agenda.
Let's listen.
(Soundbite of president's address to U.N.
General Assembly)
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: Freedom by its nature cannot be imposed.
It must be chosen.
From Beirut to Baghdad, people are making the choice for freedom, and the nation's gathered in this chamber must make a choice as well.
Will we support the moderates and reformers who are working for change across the Middle East or will we yield the future to the terrorists and extremists?
America has made its choice.
We will stand with the moderates and reformers.
So let's do some Monday morning quarterbacking.
The reviews coming in have talked about the president's speech being toned down, about how he has moved towards diplomacy than what he's done previously.
Why don't we start with you, Mike Meyers.
What do you say?
Is anybody listening to what George Bush has to say about this now?
Well, it's hard not to listen because he's everywhere all of the sudden.
But, you know, I don't think his speech - I must have been listening to the wrong speech.
I don't think his speech was diplomatic at all.
In fact, I'm getting a little tired of his hectoring tone, the hectoring nature of his voice.
It always sounds like he's reading from a script, that every speech he has is scripted and he's reading a homework assignment.
He, I believe, should have said to the United Nations that it's the best chance for peace and that the United States cannot be the world's policemen.
You cannot have a situation of creating democracies through U.S.
military occupation.
He had - he lacked the vision thing.

There was an opportunity for him, particularly given Secretary-General Annan's farewell address, to set the vision and to say why the United Nations is such an important world body and how the United States is going to work with the U.N.
in order to achieve world peace and desirable change.
If you swing the sword - yeah.
OK.
A lot of the news over the past week has been about trade and about tariffs, and there is some speculation that if this escalates, this will have real consequences in the Midwest.
I'm wondering, how is that conversation playing where you are?
Well, I do think that there's real anxiety about all of this.
But, you know, having watched Donald Trump bluff in the past and back off, I don't think that we're at the stage where people are ready to bail.

On the other hand, you know, if, in fact, this escalates, and the Chinese begin to slap major tariffs, you are going to see this hitting the bottom lines of many of the individuals and the communities that backed Donald Trump in the election.
And I think then you'll have a real palpable sense of betrayal that will not help Republicans in the midterm elections at all.
That's Charlie Sykes.
He's a conservative commentator and author, longtime host of an influential political talk show based in Wisconsin.
He joined us from member station WUWM in Milwaukee.
Charlie, thanks so much for joining us.
Thank you.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""CLOSER TO FINE"")
(Singing) I'm trying to tell you something about my life.
